Abstract: Nonconjugated redox-active polymers have emerged as promising materials for energy storage applications, particularly in the field of batteries. This review explores the electron transfer mechanisms, energy storage capabilities, and chemical versatility of these polymers. We examine the unique characteristics that distinguish nonconjugated redox-active polymers from their conjugated counterparts, focusing on their electron transfer kinetics and conductivity. The article discusses various polymer architectures and their impact on electrochemical performance, highlighting recent advancements in polymer design for improved energy density and cycling stability. Additionally, we investigate the chemical versatility of these materials, exploring their potential applications beyond energy storage. This comprehensive analysis provides insights into the current state of nonconjugated redox-active polymer research and identifies future directions for optimizing their performance in battery technologies and other emerging fields.
